fr.sorbonne_u.utils.aclocks

Class AcceleratedClock

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sorbonne_u.utils.aclocks.AcceleratedClock
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class AcceleratedClock
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    The class AcceleratedClock implements a relative clock working on an accelerated time based on the class Instant in parallel with a Unix epoch time underlying system clock; its main purpose is to ease the implementation of time-triggered test scenarios, especially for cyber-physical but also for timed test scenarios in general.

    Description

    The purpose of this class is to provide a clock that keeps track of the time in two different time lines. One time line is given by instants, represented as java.time.Instant, that is used to express scenarios, especially in test scenarios. The second time line is the Unix epoch time provided by the hardware clock. The goal is that this clock can be shared among several processes to synchronise their actions on the same accelerated time in a time-triggered approach. Moreover, an acceleration factor can be given so that the instant time is keep synchronised with the Unix epoch time modulo the acceleration factor from some start time: 

                             start instant              accelerated instant
 Accelerated instants -------|------------------------------|--------------
                              \             ^              /
                               \            |             /
                                \      acceleration      /
                                 \        factor        /
                                  \         |          /
 Unix epoch time      -------------|------------------|-------------------
                             start time         Unix epoch time

    With this class, one can plan scenarios in human readable Instant but can compute delays and time in Unix epoch time corresponding to the instants in order to schedule tasks on Java thread pools so that they execute in an accelerated real time line.

    The clock is instantiated with an acceleration factor, a start instant and a start time corresponding to the Unix epoch system time. By default, the Unix epoch start time is given by System.currentTimeMillis(), but a specific value can be given to help creating several clock instances with the same Unix epoch start time as base time for scheduling. Also, by default, the start instant is given by Instant.now(), but a specific value can be given to simplify the elaboration of time scenarios with an easily manageable base time. The class offers methods to go from one time line to the other.

    To go from a Unix epoch system time to an instant, there are:

    • currentInstant takes the current Unix epoch system time given by System.currentTimeMillis() and converts it in an instant based on the start instant and taking into account the acceleration factor.
    • instantOfEpochInNanos performs the same computation but with a given a Unix epoch system time in nanoseconds passed as parameter rather than the current system time.

    To compute real time delays from instants, there are:

    • unixEpochTimeInNanosFromInstant takes an accelerated instant and return the corresponding Unix epoch time in nanoseconds given the Unix epoch start time.
    • nanoDelayUntilAcceleratedInstant takes an accelerated instant return the delay in nanoseconds from the current system time to the moment in Unix epoch real time at which some computation must be scheduled on a thread to execute as if it happens at the provided instant in accelerated time. For example, assume a clock accelerated 10 times is started at an instant I and a Unix epoch system time T. Then, assume that the program wants to schedule some computation to be executed 10 minutes after I in accelerated time. In this situation, the call nanoDelayUntilAcceleratedInstant(I.plusSeconds(600)) returns the delay d in real time (and in nanoseconds) to be used immediately in order to schedule the computation so that it will execute at I.plusSeconds(600) in accelerated time.
    • nanoDelayToAcceleratedInstantFromEpochTime performs the same computation but to give a delay from a given system epoch time in milliseconds rather than from the current system time.

    The computations of the delays are correct only after the start time has been reached. The method startTimeNotReached allows to test if the start has not been reached yet. When the start time is still in the future, the method waitUntilStart will block the calling thread until the start time is reached. The method waitingDelayUntilStartInMillis returns the remaining time in milliseconds until the start time.

    Good practices

    On standard (non real time) Unix systems, hardware clocks are in practice precise to the milliseconds and even to the tens of milliseconds. Therefore, care must be taken not to plan scenarios where the delays between scheduled actions are less than these values. And indeed, this is even more important when large acceleration factors are used as the acceleration factor equally applies to the precision (for example, on my Mac, the precision is usually around a few milliseconds; with an acceleration factor of 10, the useful precision (shortest accurate delays between scheduled actions before acceleration) is more a few tens of milliseconds, and with an acceleration factor 100, the precision is no more than a few hundreds of milliseconds, hence a few tenth of a second.

    The Instant class offers quite flexible ways to compute instants from other instants, such as adding some amount of seconds to an existing instant with the method Instant.plusSeconds(long). This allows an AcceleratedClock user to build scenario patterns like: 

     AcceleratedClock ac =new AcceleratedClock(
                              TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS.toNanos(
                                      System.currentTimeMillis() + 5000L),
                          Instant.parse("2022-11-07T06:00:00.000Z"),
                          1.0);
          ac.waitUntilStart();
          Instant observed = ac.currentInstant();
          Instant nextAction = observed.plusSeconds(5);
          long delay = ac.nanoDelayUntilInstant(nextAction);
          Thread.sleep(TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS.toMillis(delay));
          // perform some action

    This kind of scenarios tends to drift as the imprecision of the hardware clock and of the scheduling will accumulate over the computation of series of instants from imprecise observed instants.

    To avoid as much as possible imprecision in test scenarios executions, it is better to:

    1. Choose an acceleration factor such that when applied to the shortest delay between two scheduled actions, it will not give a waiting time that is under 10 milliseconds between two successive actions (to be adapted to the precision of your operating system and hardware).
    2. Prepare test scenarios with absolute Instant only i.e., instants that are created from a string like Instant.parse("2022-11-07T06:00:00.000Z"). With absolute instants, the computation of delays tends to absorb the drift along the scenario execution, hence leaving less imprecision over whole executions.

    White-box Invariant

     invariant       true        // no more invariant

    Black-box Invariant

     invariant       getAccelerationFactor() > 0.0
 invariant       getStartEpochNanos() > 0
 invariant       getStartInstant() != null

      • AcceleratedClock

        public AcceleratedClock(java.lang.String clockURI,
                        double accelerationFactor)
        create an accelerated clock with the given acceleration factor, taking the both start times as now.

        Contract

         pre     clockURI != null && !clockURI.isEmpty()
 pre     accelerationFactor > 0.0
 post    getStartEpochNanos() <= TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS.toNanos(System.currentTimeMillis())
 post    getStartInstant().equals(Instant.ofEpochMilli(TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS.toMillis(getStartEpochNanos())))
 post    getAccelerationFactor() == accelerationFactor
        Parameters:
        clockURI - URI attributed to the clock.
        accelerationFactor - acceleration factor to be applied.

      • AcceleratedClock

        public AcceleratedClock(java.lang.String clockURI,
                        long unixEpochStartTimeInNanos,
                        double accelerationFactor)
        create an accelerated clock with the given start time in Unix epoch time in nanoseconds and the given acceleration factor taking the start instant as Instant.ofEpochMilli(unixEpochStartTimeInNanos/1000000).

        Contract

         pre     clockURI != null && !clockURI.isEmpty()
 pre     unixEpochStartTimeInNanos > 0
 pre     accelerationFactor > 0.0
 post    getStartEpochNanos() == unixEpochStartTimeInNanos
 post    getStartInstant().equals(Instant.ofEpochMilli(TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS.toMillis(getStartEpochNanos())))
 post    getAccelerationFactor() == accelerationFactor
        Parameters:
        clockURI - URI attributed to the clock.
        unixEpochStartTimeInNanos - start time in Unix epoch time in nanoseconds.
        accelerationFactor - acceleration factor to be applied.

      • unixEpochTimeInNanosFromInstant

        compute the Unix epoch real time corresponding to an accelerated instant i.

        Contract

         pre     i.isAfter(getStartInstant())
 post    return > getStartEpochNanos()
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the Unix epoch real time corresponding to i.

      • nanoDelayUntilInstant

        public long nanoDelayUntilInstant(java.time.Instant i)
        compute real time delay from now to the real time at which to schedule immediately the execution given an accelerated Instant at which the execution must occur. For example, if C is the current time (from System.currentTimeMillis()) and I the accelerated Instant, I is first converted into a real Unix epoch time R using the stored start Instant and the Unix epoch time start time, which give the result as R - C.

        Contract

         pre     acceleratedInstant != null && acceleratedInstant.isAfter(currentInstant())
 post    return >= 0
        Parameters:
        i - accelerated Instant at which to the execution must occur.
        Returns:
        real time delay from now to the real time at which to schedule immediately the execution.

      • nanoDelayToAcceleratedInstantFromEpochTime

        public long nanoDelayToAcceleratedInstantFromEpochTime(long baseEpochTimeInMillis,
                                                       java.time.Instant acceleratedInstant)
        compute real time delay from baseEpochTimeInMillis to the real time at which to schedule the execution given an accelerated Instant at which this execution must occur in accelerated time. For example, if C is the baseEpochTimeInMillis and I the accelerated Instant, I is first converted into a real Unix epoch time R using the stored start Instant and the Unix epoch time start time from which the result is obtained as R - C.

        Contract

         pre     TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS.toNanos(baseEpochTimeInMillis) > getStartEpochNanos()
 pre     acceleratedInstant != null && acceleratedInstant.isAfter(instantOfEpochInNanos(TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS.toNanos(baseEpochTimeInMillis))
 post    return > 0
        Parameters:
        baseEpochTimeInMillis - base time from which the delay is computed as Unix epoch time in milliseconds.
        acceleratedInstant - accelerated Instant at which to the execution must occur.
        Returns:
        real time delay from now to the real time at which to schedule immediately the execution.
